CIPHER.65.cipherString: I am happy to write this letter of recommendation for Fred. he was a student in my Calculus ii class, and earned a B. However, he earned an a in Computer Science ii, which might be more relevant for the internship you describe.
CIPHER.65.question: Fred recently asked his favorite professor, who teaches Calculus ii, for a letter of recommendation. He's applying for an internship during the summer after his freshman year of college, and I recommend that you do the same thing yourself someday; internships are important! Fred is applying for a programming internship, so he also provided the grades he earned in Computer Science ii. The letter of recommendation for the internship is an aristocrat, and the ciphertext is given below. Can you recover the plaintext?

CIPHER.45.cipherString: THE BRUSILOV OFFENSIVE HAS BEEN COSTLY EIGHT HUNDRED THOUSAND MEN WERE KILLED
CIPHER.45.question: Let us imagine that in World War One (1914-1919), this message has been sent from the Czar's general staﬀ to the Imperial War Cabinet in London, a few days after the conclusion of the Brusilov Oﬀensive (1916). The cipher used is the Vigenère Cipher. You are attempting to perform cryptanalysis. You don't know the key, yet it is known that the plaintext begins with the phrase "The Brusilov Oﬀensive." The ciphertext has been grouped in clusters of three for easy transmission. Can you recover the plaintext?

CIPHER.86.cipherString: Jane, obstruction of justice charges are gravely serious, especially trying to prevent the FBI from doing its job. Don't take this client. Love, Jennifer.
CIPHER.86.question: The following ciphertext is a patrisocrat, sent from one defense lawyer (Jennifer) to another (Jane). We do know that Jane has been oﬀered a job by an extremely famous client. The ciphertext letters have been grouped into clusters of five for easy transmission. Jennifer tends to put her name at the end of her plaintexts, as a signature. There are no other hints. Try to recover the plaintext!

CIPHER.87.cipherString: SANTA CRUZ DE LA SIERRA ES UNA CIUDAD DE BOLIVIA, CAPITAL DEL DEPARTAMENTO DE SANTA CRUZ. ES LA CIUDAD MAS POBLADA DEL PAIS Y CUENTA CON MAS DE DOS MILLONES DE HABITANTES EN SU AREA METROPOLITANA.
CIPHER.87.question: The head of the Peruvian consulate to Fortaleza, Brazil has been promoted. She is to lead the consulate in Santa Cruz, Bolivia. She is very excited to lead the delegation to this prosperous business hub (and the largest city in Bolivia). She has sent a message to her bosses to find out more about the city that will be her home for the next few years. The ciphertext, a Xenocrypt-Aristocrat, is below. Can you recover the plaintext?
CIPHER.87.translation: Santa Cruz de la Sierra is a city of Bolivia, capital of the department of Santa Cruz. It is the most populated city in the country and has more than two million inhabitants in its metropolitan area.

CIPHER.68.question: Along the margins of a pharmacopia (a medieval or rennaissance book about medicinal plants), there is a decorated pattern made of left-facing and right-facing ﬂowers. (They are denoted by p's and q's below.) Instead of alternating, or all facing the same way, it looks random. Because the book was made in the mid-17th century, a Baconian cipher is suspected. Can you recover the plaintext?

CIPHER.69.keyword: WHEN IN THE COURSE OF HUMAN EVENTS IT BECOMES NECESSARY FOR ONE PEOPLE TO DISSOLVE THE POLITICAL BANDS WHICH HAVE CONNECTED THEM WITH ANOTHER AND TO ASSUME AMONG THE POWERS OF THE EARTH, THE SEPARATE AND EQUAL STATION TO WHICH THE LAWS OF NATURE AND OF NATURE'S GOD ENTITLE THEM, A DECENT RESPECT TO THE OPINIONS OF MANKIND REQUIRES THAT THEY SHOULD DECLARE THE CAUSES WHICH IMPEL THEM TO THE SEPARATION.
CIPHER.69.cipherString: Please send a resupply delivery in the next three days we are low on food
CIPHER.69.question: The following ciphertext was encrypted with the Running Key cipher. Decrypt the message to discover the plaintext. The running key was the Declaration of Independence. (Note that the start of the Declaration of Independence has been provided for you at the beginning of this packet, for use with this question.) The ciphertext has been grouped into clusters of four for easy transmission.

CIPHER.88.cipherString: This is a disaster! Our truck was carrying thirty five tons, seventy thousand pounds, of olive oil. Now that the truck has overturned, the highway is covered with the stuff.
CIPHER.88.question: The following message was just sent from the regional office to the national office of a major food manufacturer. A few hours ago, there was an accident involving "olive oil," so that two-word phrase probably occurs somewhere in the message. As you can see, this cryptogram is an Aristocrat. Can you recover the plaintext?

CIPHER.89.question:
Allison has faithfully followed the steps of the RSA key-generation algorithm. But has forgotten the last step—how to encrypt a message. First, Here are the results from the other steps:

   e = 22765    Φ = 204108
   q = 467      n = 205013
   p = 439       d = 148681

As it comes to pass, Austin is on vacation in Hawaii, and Allison needs a document that is stored in the company safe. They are communicating via email, and both know it is very unwise to trust the security of computers in a hotel lobby. Allison needs to tell Austin his/her public key, knowing well that it can be read by untrustworthy parties. List the minimum set of numbers that Allison needs to email to Austin, in order for Austin to be able to encrypt the message.

Additionally, Austin wants to transmit the combination to the safe (which is 7946) in the response email, but encrypted with RSA. What formula should Austin compute in order to determine the ciphertext to transmit? [Your formula should have numbers and math operations, but no variables. Do not attempt to compute the final ciphertext value.]

CIPHER.90.cipherString: Dear John, Forgive this quick note, but experimenting with zebra skeletons as art might yield bad reviews on the world wide web. Love, Xena.
CIPHER.90.question: This patristocrat is the encryption of a note from Xena to John. Therefore, it probably begins with "Dear John," and is probably signed "Xena." The ciphertext letters have been grouped into clusters of five for easy transmission. Can you recover the plaintext?

CIPHER.91.cipherString: Hello old chap. How's Denmark? Egypt is a bit too warm but the pyramids were well worth seeing. Regards.
CIPHER.91.question: A senior secretary of the British diplomatic mission to Egypt has forgotten how to encrypt with the Vigenère cipher. He wants to send the following plaintext to an old friend who has just been posted to Copenhagen. Can you encrypt it for him? Since they are diplomats, they have prearranged the keyword: PEACEFUL. The ciphertext is grouped into clusters of five for easy transmission.

CIPHER.92.cipherString: Meyer Lansky began as the bookkeeper of the mafia, helped the US Navy in WWII, then rose to power, controlling casinos in Las Vegas, Cuba, and London.
CIPHER.92.question: A new FBI agent has been posted to the organized-crime unit. He is reading up on the history of 20th-century gangsters. This message is a patristocrat, sent to him by a senior agent, who spent most of his career in Las Vegas. Earlier that day, a class covered a famous gangster who was called "the bookkeeper of the mob" before ﬂeeing to Cuba. That phrase, or perhaps one similar to it, probably appears somewhere in the message. Can you recover the plaintext? The ciphertext has been grouped into clusters of five for easy transmission.

CIPHER.75.question:
Special Agent, Grace, has the following RSA public key:

   n = 109691   e = 54395

Unfortunately for her, A quantum computer has successfully factored her n

   109691 = 229 * 479

Compute the value of her private key:

CIPHER.76.question: One of Colonel Lester Hill's battalions has sent the following ciphertext to another battalion. Unsurprisingly, they are using the Hill cipher. Luckily, the encryption key is known to you. Can you decrypt the message?

CIPHER.93.question: The captain of a company in one of Lester Hill's battalions has been struck in the foot by a cannon ball. He wishes to send the following message to his commanding officer. Unsurprisingly, they are using the Hill cipher. The encryption key is given below. Can you encrypt the plaintext for him?

CIPHER.78.cipherString: I UNDERSTAND YOUR CONCERNS OLD CHAP, BUT I DOUBT MESSAGES ENCRYPTED LIKE THIS COULD BE BROKEN BY ANYONE, EVEN SOMEONE VERY CLEVER.
CIPHER.78.question: The ciphertext below is an Aristocrat. There is no hint for this one. Can you recover the ciphertext anyway?

CIPHER.79.cipherString: I WANTED TO ASK MY SUPER VISER SUM QUESTIONS, BUTT SHE TOLLED ME SHE IS GIVING BERTH SOON, WITCH SOUNDS WRITE. ITS GRATE NEWS.
CIPHER.79.question: One fellow, a recently graduated business major, is known to have phenomenally bad spelling and grammar. He uses the spell-check feature built into his email software, so every word in the plaintext can be found in a normal English dictionary. Nonetheless, the phraseology is often extremely mangled. Lastly, he encrypts the message as an aristocrat. Can you recover the plaintext?

CIPHER.85.question:
Cloe and Natalie want to communicate with each other using RSA for encryption. Cloe generates RSA keys obtaining the following values:

   e = 231079      p = 479
   d = 215107      n = 424873
   q = 887      Φ = 423508

Likewise, Natalie also generates RSA keys resulting in the values

   n = 42173      Φ = 41760
   q = 233      p = 181
   e = 29201      d = 15761

They ask each other for their public keys in order to communicate. What information do they each need to transmit in response?

Next, determine what formula Natalie needs to compute in order to transmit the plaintext value 3948 to Cloe. [Do not actually compute the ciphertext, but write a formula using numbers and math operations. Your formula should not contain variables.]

CIPHER.94.question: A rural safe-house has been stormed by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, but they found it empty. The terrorists have already ﬂed. It is known that they were using the affine cipher, but they used a diﬀerent function each time. The ciphertext below encrypts where they have ﬂed to. While the plaintext was burnt, a tiny fragment showing the start of the plaintext has survived in the fireplace. (The plaintext starts with "NE.") Can you recover the rest of the plaintext?

CIPHER.82.question: Angela and Grace are accountants for a very large bank, and have started a friendship. They communicate via email, because they live thousands of miles apart. Grace gets curious and asks Angela the year that she was born. Angela doesn’t mind telling Grace, but they know that the bank monitors all employee emails, and Angela is afraid of being the victim of age discrimination. Therefore, Grace suggests that they use RSA, and Grace provides his public key: (4187, 2785). Angela replies with the ciphertext 2139. Grace’s private key is 217. In what year was Angela born?

CIPHER.83.keyword: WE THE PEOPLE OF THE UNITED STATES, IN ORDER TO FORM A MORE PERFECT UNION, ESTABLISH JUSTICE, INSURE DOMESTIC TRANQUILITY, PROVIDE FOR THE COMMON DEFENSE, PROMOTE THE GENERAL WELFARE, AND SECURE THE BLESSINGS OF LIBERTY TO OURSELVES AND OUR POSTERITY, DO ORDAIN AND ESTABLISH THIS CONSTITUTION FOR THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA.
CIPHER.83.cipherString: WE ARE RUNNING LOW ON INSECT REPELLANT AND FOOD BUT HAVE ENOUGH WATER PLEASE RESUPPLY SOON
CIPHER.83.question: Encrypt the following message using the Running Key cipher. For the running key, the US constitution has been chosen. (Note that the start of the US Constitution has been provided for you at the beginning of this packet, for use with this question.) The ciphertext has been grouped into clusters of four for easy transmission.

CIPHER.84.cipherString: It is truly surprising what a narrow mind (what a blind outlook) a man, brought up with practically no opposition to his boyhood wants, can attain, though brought into contact with indisputably important data for improving his town.
CIPHER.84.question: The following ciphertext is an Aristocrat taken from the novel Gadsby, by Ernest Vincent Wright. That novel is special because the letter E appears nowhere inside that 50,000 word novel. Other than that, there is no hint. Can you recover the plaintext?
